parent.name: Gender and Sexuality Studies in Literature

data.name: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality Studies
data.description: This course provides an introduction to the study of gender and sexuality in the larger field of cultural studies. It covers topics such as the construction of gender and sexuality, gender roles, gender-based violence, and LGBTQ+ identities. It also examines how gender and sexuality intersect with power, culture, and politics.

prerequisites: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality Studies

data.name: Gender Identity and Expression
data.description: This course explores the social, cultural, and psychological aspects of gender identity and expression. It covers topics such as gender norms, gender roles, gender-based discrimination, and gender identity and expression in a variety of contexts. It examines how gender identity and expression are shaped by social and cultural factors, as well as how they impact personal and professional lives.

prerequisites: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality Studies

data.name: Gender and Sexuality in Popular Culture
data.description: This course examines how gender and sexuality are represented in popular culture. It covers topics such as gender roles, gender stereotypes, gender-based violence, and LGBTQ+ representation in media. It examines how popular culture shapes gender and sexuality, as well as how it is shaped by gender and sexuality.

prerequisites: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality Studies
Gender and Sexuality in Popular Culture

data.name: Gender and Sexuality in Literature
data.description: This course examines how gender and sexuality are represented in literature. It covers topics such as gender roles, gender stereotypes, gender-based violence, and LGBTQ+ representation in literature. It examines how literature shapes gender and sexuality, as well as how it is shaped by gender and sexuality.

data.name: Introduction to Psychology
data.description: This course provides an overview of the field of psychology, focusing on its scientific basis and its application in the modern world. It discusses the various research methods used to study the human mind and behavior, including surveys, experiments, observations, and interviews. Additionally, this course examines the different psychological theories and approaches used to explain individual and group behavior.

data.name: Developmental Psychology
data.description: This course provides an in-depth look at human development from birth to old age. It examines the physical, cognitive, and social/emotional changes that occur throughout the lifespan, as well as the influences of heredity and environment on behavior. The course also covers a range of topics related to development, including language acquisition, moral development, and the effects of abuse and neglect.

data.name: Biological Bases of Behavior
data.description: This course explores the biological basis of behavior, focusing on the structure and function of the nervous system, the endocrine system, and the immune system. It also examines the role of hormones and neurotransmitters in behavior, as well as the impact of genetics and evolutionary processes. The course also discusses the influence of environmental factors on behavior, including nutrition, drugs, and stress.

data.name: Cognitive Psychology
data.description: This course examines the cognitive processes underlying human behavior, including perception, memory, language, problem-solving, and decision-making. It also explores the effects of mental illness on cognition and the use of cognitive therapies to treat psychological disorders. The course also covers topics such as the development of artificial intelligence and the implications of cognitive research for society.

data.name: Social Psychology
data.description: This course studies the influence of social factors on behavior, including group dynamics, attitudes, and socialization. It examines how individuals interact with one another and how these interactions can shape behavior. The course also discusses the effects of prejudice and discrimination on behavior, as well as the impact of social media on interpersonal relationships.

data.name: Abnormal Psychology
data.description: This course examines different types of psychological disorders, including anxiety, mood, and personality disorders. It discusses the causes and symptoms of these disorders, as well as the various treatment approaches. The course also covers topics such as the legal and ethical implications of mental illness and the use of psychotropic medications.

data.name: Neuropsychology
data.description: This course provides an in-depth look at the relationship between the brain and behavior. It examines the structure and function of the various parts of the brain and how they contribute to behavior. The course also discusses the effects of brain injuries on behavior, as well as the use of neuroimaging techniques to study the brain. Additionally, the course covers topics related to the diagnosis and treatment of neurological disorders.

data.description: This course will provide students with an in-depth look at the complex ideologies and practices of various religious traditions. The course will examine the role of religious organizations in shaping society, as well as their interaction with other social, cultural, and political institutions. Additionally, the course will explore the ways in which religious organizations have adapted to changing social contexts.

data.name: Religious Movements and Conflicts

The course will examine the role of religion in international conflicts, as well as the ways in which religious movements have shaped history and society. Additionally, the course will explore the ways in which different religious traditions have interacted with each other, and how those interactions have impacted the nature of religious expression in modern society.

The course also examines the impact of gender and sexuality on social institutions such as the family, education, politics, and the economy.

It examines how gender and sexuality are portrayed in various cultural contexts and the role of media in constructing and perpetuating gender and sexual identities. Topics include gender in television, film, magazines, and advertising, as well as the implications of these representations for individuals and society.

data.name: Introduction to Archaeology
data.description: This course provides a broad overview of the field of archaeology, including a wide range of topics, such as archaeological theory, methods, and the history of archaeology. It is designed to provide an introduction to the field and to provide a foundation for more advanced courses.

data.name: Introduction to Zooarchaeology
data.description: This course provides an introduction to zooarchaeology, a sub-discipline of archaeology that focuses on the study of animal bones. The course covers the basics of zooarchaeological analysis, from excavation and identification of animal bones to the interpretation of animal remains in archaeological contexts.

data.name: Taphonomy
data.description: This course focuses on the study of animal bones in archaeological contexts. It covers the processes of decay and preservation of animal bones, as well as the ways in which animal remains can be used to interpret past environments and human behavior.

data.name: Advanced Zooarchaeology
data.description: This course provides an advanced overview of the field of zooarchaeology. The course covers topics such as the use of isotopic and molecular methods to study animal bones, as well as the use of animal bones in reconstructing past environments and human behavior.

data.name: Introductory Biology
data.description: Introductory course to the field of biology, covering the basics of the scientific method, cell structure, and genetics.

data.name: Principles of Genetics
data.description: Course covering genetics, including Mendelian genetics, gene expression, population genetics, and genetic engineering.

data.name: Introductory Ecology
data.description: Course covering the basics of ecology, including the study of populations, communities, ecosystems, and biomes.

data.name: Animal Physiology
data.description: Course covering the physiology of animals, including the anatomy and physiology of organs, the nervous system, and the endocrine system.

data.name: Introduction to Zoology
data.description: Course introducing the study of zoology, including the classification of animals, evolution of animals, and behavior.
